sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: What's this a Booke?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: [*] No, tis my learned trencher
Which Schollers sometimes eate, Euclid they call it,
In my opinion this wing and legge
Is worth all bodies mathematicall;
Now let's dispute in Greek, to the Kings health.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: To me, ile pledge.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: It shall goe round.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: And why doe you thinke my friend the King
Came hither with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: To dine.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Thy braines are in thy guts, you shall heare more,
Whats this?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Potato Bulley.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: A cup of wine to cleare the passage, so,
Here is as they say Latine: here is Greeke, and
Here is for ought I know an Hebrew roote, most learnedly
Met together.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Helle be drunke presently.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Bottle in battle ray, present, give fire, so as
You were; have they good stomacks Iacamo?
How feeds the King?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: He was very pleasant with your Lady,
But the Duke feedes upon her lookes.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: My Ladies health, my Lady little Domittillaes health.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Well said, about, about.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I am about another to our reverent Lady Simphorora,
So, so, this wine they say will make us see things double,
Here is but one Leg visible; well for this favour
Gentlemen if I be fore'd to live in court Ile make
You all in time, who can write or reade among you?

sp.speaker: Both Iacamo and Pietro
sp.l: None, none, we scorne it.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You shall have all preferment trust to me,
And marke my steps, heere to the curteous drinker,
Now doe I finde a noble constitution in me, now
Could I leape, would thou wert any living Lady
In my way now.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Away, the Lords are risen.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: The Lords doe rise and fall.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Hees paid, the King will come this way.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Every man goe his owne way, I wonnot see
The King for all this

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: This is the Ladies Secretary, pray my Lords
Be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Dee heare no body say he saw me, I wonnot
Be seene yet.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Though he be made a spectacle, but leave him
'Twas a handsome entertainement o'the sudden.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: A pretty unting dinner, but did you not
Observe with what intention the Duke
Shot eyes on Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: And the King
Applied all his discourse to her, I know not
He has made no vow against a second marriage
But if he choose at home and looke at beauty.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Shees a very pretty talking Lady.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: Very ingenious.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: And with your favour, though she be no Court Lady,
Shee wants no confidence.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: What if the Duke be taken with her?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Let him be taken a bed with her, tis my opinion
My Lord Montalto wonnot die for greefe o[*]t.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: They are here.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Your grace is sad, excuse
My dilligence to waite on you, I could wish
If it made no intru[*]ion on your thoughts,
I had opportunity to expresse
What might not be unworthy of your patience.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To me.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: The King.
This way Ladies to the Garden, let me have
The honour to attend you.
